``` ::: ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} Lateral border of the ischial tuberosity @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Insertion {#insertion} Intertrochanteric crest of the femur @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Innervation {#innervation} Sacral plexus Direct Branches ([L5]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l5 >}}), [S1]({{< var ref-nerve-root.s1 >}})) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Action {#action} **Hip**: External rotation @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ::: {.callout-note} The QF may extend or flex the hip depending on its position @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: # Palpation {#palpation} 1. Position the patient in prone @bielTrailGuideBody2019. 1. locate: @bielTrailGuideBody2019. 1. Posterior aspect of Greater trochanter @bielTrailGuideBody2019. 1. Ischial tuberosity @bielTrailGuideBody2019. 1. Bisect these two landmarks and place your fingerpads here @bielTrailGuideBody2019. 1. Press firmly *through* the more superficial Gluteus maximus muscle belly @bielTrailGuideBody2019. 1. Strum vertically over the QF muscle belly @bielTrailGuideBody2019. :::{layout-ncol="2"} ### Passive tension You can passively tense and slack the quadratus femoris by flexing the knee to 90° then moving between internal rotation (tension) to external rotation (slack), which should cause the quadratus femoris to palpably increase in tension @bielTrailGuideBody2019. :::
